citations.narrative:
* Eleven puppies less than 16 weeks old and weaned were not officially identified at the time of inspection. These puppies
from two separate litters were observed comingling in one outdoor enclosure. Official identification is needed to ensure
that each animal’s identity can be known with certainty, meet record bookkeeping requirements and to facilitate the
inspection process. The licensee must identify all puppies with an acceptable form of identification. The acceptable
methods of identification include a cage card (if litters are not comingled), an official tag as described in § 2.51, a
distinctive and legible tattoo marking or a plastic-type collar that is acceptable to the Administrator. In addition, the
licensee is allowed to use microchips as an official form of identification. Correct by 9/21/23.

* Official USDA forms (7005's) animal on hand sheets had 13 dogs recorded but there were 25 adult dogs counted by the
inspector. In addition, the cage card information on four enclosures containing 14 (unweaned ) puppies did not have
puppy identification, breed or the sex. When the records and dogs and puppies currently at the facility do not match it
makes the records incomplete. Complete and accurate records are needed to ensure each animal’s identity can be known
with certainty, track the movement of animals and to facilitate the inspection process. The licensee must maintain
complete and accurate records of all dogs at all times at their facility. The licensee must make, keep, and maintain
records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the full and correct information required concerning each dog or cat
purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which
is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. Correct by 10/7/23.

* Documentation of the program of exercise for 25 dogs could not be found at time of facility inspection. Exercise is
necessary for the physical health and well-being of all dogs. The exercise plan ensures that whatever the licensee is
doing whether that be floor space or other is sufficient to meet the exercise needs of the dog. Failure to have a completed
and signed exercise plan does not ensure the exercise requirements are being addressed. The licensee must develop an
exercise plan with the attending veterinarian that documents the frequency, method, and duration of exercise for each
animal. The plan must ensure that all animals are receiving an adequate opportunity for exercise and physical movement.
This plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must be made available to the APHIS inspector upon
request. Correct by 10/7/23.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
* Cobwebs and dust were observed accumulating on the interior walls and metal entryway gates in the whelp building.
Four adult dogs are in contact with the affected surfaces located in sheltered housing. This indicates a living area exists
for insects. Unsanitary living conditions are created if the affected area is not kept clean. This could lead to health issues
for the animals. The licensee must ensure that all buildings and surrounding grounds must be kept clean and in good
repair to protect the animals from injury, to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices required in this sub part, and to
reduce or eliminate breeding and living areas for rodents and other pests and vermin. Correct by 9/21/23.

* Documentation of the written program of veterinary care for 25 dogs could not be found at the time of inspection. The
program of veterinary care is a written agreement between the licensee and the attending veterinarian and is required.
The program of veterinarian care establishes standards of care for the animals. A completed written program of veterinary
care is important for the care of the animals and ensures clear and accurate communication between the facility and the
attending veterinarian. The licensee must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed,
documented in writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. The licensee must keep and maintain the written
program and make it available for APHIS inspection. Correct by 10/7/23.

* Documentation of the last recorded scheduled visit by the attending veterinarian could not be found at the time of
inspection. Regularly scheduled visits are important to determine if all aspects of animal care (nutrition, health,
environment, water, and air quality, etc.) are being provided to the dogs. The licensee must have regularly scheduled
visits, not less than once every 12 months, by the attending veterinarian to all premises where animals are kept, to assess
and ensure the adequacy of veterinary care and other aspects of animal care and use. Correct by
10/7/23.

* Documentation of the last recorded physical examination for 25 adult dogs could not be found at the time of inspection.
Physical examination of every dog on the premise is necessary to evaluate each dog for its overall internal and external
physical body condition. In addition, the physical examination will be able to evaluate the overall condition and health of
the hair coat, feet, ears, and eyes. The licensee must have a complete physical examination from head to tail of each dog
by the attending veterinarian not less than once every 12 months. Correct by 10/7/23.

* Documentation of the last recorded date for annual rabies vaccination, heartworm, and fecal float testing for 25 dogs
could not be found at the time of inspection. Annual rabies vaccinations, heartworm and fecal float testing are important
for the health of the animals. Heartworm and fecal float testing are done to ensure that there are no active internal
parasites. Heartworms are serious parasites that are transmitted by insect bites. The licensee must ensure that all dogs
are receiving vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus, and distemper)
and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in
accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. Correct by 10/7/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(2) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
* Eleven puppies less than 16 weeks old and weaned were not officially identified at the time of inspection. These puppies 
from two separate litters were observed comingling in one outdoor enclosure. Official identification is needed to ensure

2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
* Official USDA forms (7005's) animal on hand sheets had 13 dogs recorded but there were 25 adult dogs counted by the

3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
* Documentation of the program of exercise for 25 dogs could not be found at time of facility inspection. Exercise is 
necessary for the physical health and well-being of all dogs. The exercise plan ensures that whatever the licensee is 
doing whether that be floor space or other is sufficient to meet the exercise needs of the dog. Failure to have a completed

This plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must be made available to the APHIS inspector upon 
request. Correct by 10/7/23. 
3.11(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
* Cobwebs and dust were observed accumulating on the interior walls and metal entryway gates in the whelp building. 
Four adult dogs are in contact with the affected surfaces located in sheltered housing. This indicates a living area exists

3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* Documentation of the written program of veterinary care for 25 dogs could not be found at the time of inspection. The 
program of veterinary care is a written agreement between the licensee and the attending veterinarian and is required. 
The program of veterinarian care establishes standards of care for the animals. A completed written program of veterinary

Physical examination of every dog on the premise is necessary to evaluate each dog for its overall internal and external

3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs.

* Documentation of the last recorded date for annual rabies vaccination, heartworm, and fecal float testing for 25 dogs

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
